headline: Review: ‘’Til Madness Do Us Part’ Finds Hell and Humanity
summary_short: Wang Bing’s documentary about a mental hospital in China is overlong but sporadically extraordinary.

headline: Review: ‘(T)error’ Documentary Follows an Informant in an F.B.I. Inquiry
summary_short: This documentary raises questions about the agency’s methods, as an informant is told to persist with an inquiry after he concludes that its target is not a serious threat.
director: Lyric R. Cabral, David Felix Sutcliffe

headline: Review: ‘#Horror’ Finds the Fear in Cyberbullying and Social Media Threats

headline: Review: In ‘1 Night,’ a Hotel, 2 Couples, a Bad Prom and a Reckoning

headline: Open Marriage Trying to Induce Same

headline: High School Is Over, but the Angst Is Not

headline: Review: In ‘10.000 km,’ Lovers an Ocean Apart Struggle to Connect

headline: Review: ‘1000 Rupee Note,’ a Poor Widow’s Blessing and Curse
summary_short: In this film, set in the Maharashtra State of India, a villager sets off on a fraught shopping trip after receiving a few 1,000-rupee notes at a political rally.

headline: Review: In ‘11:55,’ a Marine Returns Home to Another War

summary_short: Mr. Bay has moderately scaled back his extreme-cinema approach for the story about the attack on the American diplomatic mission in 2012.

summary_short: A German biopic tells the story of Georg Elser, a carpenter who tried to blow up the Führer in 1939.

headline: Review: In ‘32 Pills,’ a Filmmaker Investigates Her Sister’s Death

headline: What’s a Nice Girl Doing in This Hole?

summary_short: This sequel to Tim Burton’s “Alice in Wonderland,” directed by James Bobin, offers a world of grotesque overabundance cluttered with special-effects gadgetry.

summary_short: In “I Don’t Know How She Does It,” Sarah Jessica Parker portrays a woman who “has it all,” though the movie inadvertently makes her character’s supposedly golden life look like a living hell.

headline: Review: In Search of a Dying Tongue in ‘I Dream in Another Language’
summary_short: In the film, a linguist seeks to keep a language alive, but the only two men who speak it aren’t interested.

headline: Review: ‘I Saw the Light,’ a Hank Williams Biopic

writer: Marc Abraham, Colin Escott (book), George Merritt (book), William MacEwen (book)

headline: Heady Times in Exotic Iceland
summary_short: Andrea Sisson and Pete Ohs feature Iceland’s natural wonders and Ms. Sisson’s philosophical ruminations in “I Send You This Place.”

headline: Review: ‘I Touched All Your Stuff,’ a Documentary About a Technician’s Story
summary_short: An American computer technician serving time in a Brazilian jail recounts his ill-fated obsession with a mysterious femme fatale who may or may not exist.

display_title: I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You
headline: Moods and Messages From the Earth
summary_short: As singular as its title, “I Travel Because I Have To, I Come Back Because I Love You” embraces road movie, personal journal and trancelike study of arcing grief.

display_title: I Will Follow You Into the Dark
headline: Afterlife? What Afterlife?
summary_short: In “I Will Follow You Into the Dark,” Mischa Barton is a religious skeptic whose boyfriend mysteriously disappears.

headline: Review: ‘I, Olga Hepnarova,’ Carrying Out a Vow of Vengeance
summary_short: This Czech film gives a haunting account of the life of the mentally ill young woman who killed eight people in Prague in 1973.

headline: Review: ‘I, Tonya.’ I, Punching Bag. I, Punch Line.

headline: Review: In ‘I.T.,’ Smart House, Dumb Owner

headline: Review: In ‘Ice Age: Collision Course,’ a Squirrel Reorders the Universe
summary_short: The fifth movie in the “Ice Age” franchise includes endless wisecracks and family-values twaddle, but the 3-D animation packs some punch.

headline: A Woman With a Son, but Not a Country

headline: It’s Dark, Twisted and Unexplainable

headline: Review: Diamonds Are a Mighty Tease in ‘Imperfections,’ a Noir Set in Chicago

summary_short: A young man’s trauma is the mystery of “Implanted,” a first feature from Thomas Verrette.

headline: Review: Don’t Mess With the Dog in ‘In a Valley of Violence’

display_title: In Heaven Underground: The Weissensee Jewish Cemetery

summary_short: This documentary, directed by Joe Berlinger, explores the Armenian genocide through old footage of survivors and insights from historians.

headline: A Frankenstein Story for the Digital Age
summary_short: A minor addition to the tiny genre of feminist science fiction films, "Teknolust" is a benign, digital-age Frankenstein story about a mousy genetic research scientist, Rosetta Stone (the stunning Tilda Swinton, struggling to look plain by donning a curly wig and oversized glasses), who uses her own DNA to create three color-coded clones.  Written and directed by Lynn Hershman Leeson, who guided Ms. Swinton to a more effective performance in the 1998 "Conceiving Ada," "Teknolust" has a lot on its mind but little on the ball when it comes to transforming thematic notions into dramatic concepts.  The most aggressive of the clones, Ruby, becomes infatuated with an irritatingly incompetent copy shop employee (ok, we got it) played by the perpetually twitchy Jeremy Davies.  Love, it seems, will help her to become real, like some sort of hormonally charged Pinocchio.  There's some potential for entertainment here, but Ms. Leeson's emphatic direction draws much of the fun from the comedy elements.  Even Ms. Swinton, usually the most restrained and elegant of performers, can be found mugging outrageously as she strains to put over the less-than-convulsive laugh lines. — Dave Kehr

headline: A Confused Boy Wants to Play, Even When Others Want to Fight

headline: Review: ‘When Two Worlds Collide’ Portrays a Battle for the Amazon
